facts.fact_text: Brazil posted a USD 4.34 billion trade surplus in January 2026, up 85.8% year on year.

evidences.evidence_text: Brazil posted a USD 4.34 billion trade surplus in January 2026, up 85.8% year on year

facts.fact_text: Purchases abroad fell 9.8% to USD 20.8 billion, led by a 30.2% plunge in extractive industry imports.

evidences.evidence_text: Purchases abroad fell 9.8% to USD 20.8 billion, led by a 30.2% plunge in extractive industry imports.

facts.fact_text: Exports edged down 1% to USD 25.1 billion, with extractive sales falling 3.4% and transformation industry exports slipping 0.5%, partly offset by a 2.1% rise in agricultural shipments.

evidences.evidence_text: Exports edged down 1% to USD 25.1 billion, with extractive sales falling 3.4% and transformation industry exports slipping 0.5%, partly offset by a 2.1% rise in agricultural shipments.

facts.fact_text: Imports from Argentina (-13.6%), the US (-10.9%), China (-4.9%) and the EU (-11.5%) all decreased.

evidences.evidence_text: Imports from Argentina (-13.6%), the US (-10.9%), China (-4.9%) and the EU (-11.5%) all decreased.

facts.fact_text: Exports to Argentina (-24.5%), the US (-25.5%) and the EU (-6.2%) declined, while sales to China jumped 17.4%.

evidences.evidence_text: Exports to Argentina (-24.5%), the US (-25.5%) and the EU (-6.2%) declined, while sales to China jumped 17.4%.

evidence.evidence_text: Brazil posted a USD 4.34 billion trade surplus in January 2026, up 85.8% year on year, largely driven by a sharp drop in imports.
Brazil posted a USD 4.34 billion trade surplus in January 2026, up 85.8% year on year, largely driven by a sharp drop in imports.
